Ian Badcoe wrote:

>>One of the major benefits of pruning though is that it keeps the
>>complexity of the population as a whole in check, which keeps the NEAT
>>search running at an optimal speed.
>>    
>>
>
>Except that if the pruned species are fitter they will supplant the 
>un-pruned ones and if they are not, then you don't have the option of 
>pruning anyway.
>
>Er... maybe...
>
>Must think about it some more...
>  
>
Yeh, when dealing with speciation, ideas that at first seem intuitive 
and simple can actually get quite complex. I'm not saying that 
per-species pruning wouldn't work OK, but I always try and keep things 
as simple as possible. So I'm working on population wide pruning - which 
works well BTW - and perhaps after some thought if we recon that per 
species is likely to have a greater benefit then I'll give it a go!

Colin.
